content.description:
Climb the left arete starting bunched up with your back on the detached rock and hands on good holds.   

  Decent warm-up.
content.protection: Pads.  The crux is pulling up and top out is easy.
content.location: On the good face of the smaller boulder, locate the left arete left of the problem Hit it and Quit it.

content.description:
Sit start beneath the crack and make a hard pull up using face holds into the crack then move upward with increasing ease using the combination of face and crack.  Trends right for the topout.   

  A good route to warm-up on.
content.location: This is located on the smaller boulder.  Locate the crack on the leftside of the face.

content.description: Stand start the steep, proud face. This is easier if you are tall and harder if short. It is classic regardless of height.
content.location: Facing the big Dungeon Boulder, this is the steep left face.

content.description:
This has sharp, crimpy climbing up into an obvious seam with a highball exit.   

  It is pretty classic looking, but the holds down low are in a state of flux. Joel calls this a "soft V11".
content.protection: Pads. The exit is maybe 20-25 feet up, so spotters may be necessary.
content.location: This is right of Fault Line on same tall, gently overhanging face.

content.description: Sit start on the far left side of the boulder and hit the lip and traverse right to top out at the far right end of the wall.
content.location: This ascends the wall around the corner from the problem Fault Line.

pathTokens: Town Line Boulders aka South Woods

content.description: These are two blocks. Big Dungeon Boulder has some hard problems. Little Dungeon in general has easy problems.
